results.title: Regina Hall and Wanda Sykes on Hosting the Oscars
results.abstract: In an interview, the stars said they plan to keep the show moving and make sure it’s funny. But there will be a segment about the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

multimedia.caption: Wanda Sykes, left, and Regina Hall at the Loews Hollywood Hotel on Thursday. (Amy Schumer was ill.) They were not fans of the recent hostless Oscar shows.
multimedia.copyright: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

results.abstract: A guide to everything you need to know for the 94th annual Academy Awards on Sunday night.

results.title: ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ Review: It’s Messy, and Glorious
results.abstract: Michelle Yeoh stars as a stressed-out laundromat owner dragged into cosmic battle and genre chaos.

results.title: ‘The Lost City’ Review: Raiders of the 1980s Blockbusters
results.abstract: Sandra Bullock, Channing Tatum and a vamping Brad Pitt run around in a romantic adventure that you have seen before and will see again.

results.title: Oscars 2022 Predictions: Who Will Win Best Picture, Actor and Actress?
results.abstract: In an interesting year with a duel for the top award and some wide-open races, here’s how our expert is marking his ballot.

results.title: Oscars Rewind: For Halle Berry, a Bittersweet Breakthrough
results.abstract: Since she won best actress for “Monster’s Ball,” no other Black woman has taken the prize, a fact she calls “heartbreaking.”

multimedia.caption: A tearful Halle Berry accepting the Oscar in 2002.

results.title: Four Best Picture Contenders Are Remakes. Does That Matter to Oscar Voters?
results.abstract: Academy history offers clues about how “Nightmare Alley,” “West Side Story,” “CODA” and “Dune” might fare on Sunday.

multimedia.caption: Tyrone Power and Coleen Gray, left, in “Nightmare Alley,” from 1947. Rooney Mara and Bradley Cooper, right, in the new version. Both were based on a novel of the same name.
Tyrone Power and Coleen Gray, left, in “Nightmare Alley,” from 1947. Rooney Mara and Bradley Cooper, right, in the new version. Both were based on a novel of the same name.

results.title: Danny Glover on Acting, Activism and His Honorary Oscar
results.abstract: The actor and producer is receiving the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award at the Oscars. Here, he discusses a history in movies and in social justice.

multimedia.caption: “I’m an actor first because of my activism,” Danny Glover said. He has served as a Goodwill Ambassador both for UNICEF and the United Nations Development Program.
multimedia.copyright: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times

results.title: 100 Years of ‘Nosferatu,’ the Vampire Movie That Won’t Die
results.abstract: F.W. Murnau’s 1922 silent film continues to live on in the popular imagination, as a fairy tale, a meme and a cinematic revenant.

multimedia.caption: The shadow of Max Schreck as Count Orlok in a famous scene from “Nosferatu.”

results.title: You Don’t Know Much About Jay Penske. And He’s Fine With That.
results.abstract: A quiet Hollywood power broker with a famous name goes on a buying spree that has given him Rolling Stone, South by Southwest and a private island. What more does he want?

multimedia.copyright: Illustration by Tom Hodgkinson; David M. Benett/Getty Images (Jay Penske)

results.title: Streaming Took Over Hollywood. Will It Take Best Picture, Too?
results.abstract: A few years ago, the entertainment industry was arguing over whether movies on streaming services even counted as a film. Now, one is poised to win the Oscars’ top prize.
results.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling

multimedia.copyright: Kyle Grillot for The New York Times

results.title: Who Will Win Big on Oscar Night?
results.abstract: The 94th annual Academy Awards will be presented on Sunday. Here are our predictions for who will win the biggest awards.

results.title: Peter Bogdanovich Had a Vision for This Film. Now It’s Finally Being Seen.
results.abstract: “She’s Funny That Way” wasn’t exactly the movie he set out to make, but the director’s cut was feared lost. How it came to be shown at MoMA is a complicated saga.

multimedia.caption: From left, Imogen Poots, Kathryn Hahn, Owen Wilson and Rhys Ifans in the film when it was released in 2015 and titled “She’s Funny That Way.”

results.abstract: Naomi Watts stars in a true-life drama about a woman who hiked up a mountain alone and returned with some heavy, unexpected cargo.

results.title: ‘Wood and Water’ Review: The Distances Between Us
results.abstract: In this elegant feature debut about modern alienation, the German writer-director Jonas Bak casts his real-life mother as a retired secretary who travels to Hong Kong to visit her estranged son.

results.title: Rachel Zegler, ‘West Side Story’ Star, Is Invited to the Oscars After All
results.abstract: On Sunday she revealed on Instagram that she had not been invited to the ceremony, prompting an outcry. She has since been added as a presenter.

results.abstract: The theater plans to work with the Oscar-nominated film’s producers to adapt the story of a teenager torn between helping her deaf family and singing.

results.title: Hollywood Crosses the Pond
results.abstract: Liverpool, England, is a growing production hub for TV streaming services and Hollywood studios.

results.title: Vivien Leigh and Laurence Olivier’s Turbulent Relationship, Retold With Compassion
results.abstract: In “Truly, Madly,” Stephen Galloway writes about one of the 20th century’s most glamorous couples, training an eye on Leigh’s mental health struggles.
des_facet: Truly, Madly: Vivien Leigh, Laurence Olivier and the Romance of the Century (Book)
